PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Edith Ann Collins
Address: Caragana, Sask.
Birthplace: __________________

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1918
Where did you set up housekeeping? On my farm land 12 miles from Regina, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? From Montana back
For how many people did you prepare meals? Two adults, 3 kids
How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, coffee, salt, dried fruits

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50 to $3.00

Whole wheat flour? ____________________________
Was flour milled locally? No, it was bought at the store

What other grain products did you use? Corn meal
Cornmeal? 100 lbs, Whole Wheat? ___________ Farina? ___________
Other? ____________________________
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? ____________________________

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

For 1932 I was living in Regina. I got work on R.R. and for 1st 10 days I only had a bowl of rolled oats for breakfast. Worked 2 mile to work. Had a good dinner in Cook Hall on the R.R. then worked till 5 O'C. walked home ate my bowl of rolled oats and went to bed.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Coming from the states I brought with me a 5 gal coal oil can. I was thinking of getting another can of the same size as what was used in Can. I bought about 3 years later I discovered my can was only a wine measure while the ones used here were Imperial measure and mind you I was running an incubator & a brooder every spring. When I discovered how I was being cheated I brought in an extra two gal can. I handed them both to the merchant at once & please I think that will hold it this time and he never even cracked a smile but I got both cans almost filled.

I also bought me a couple of work shirts at $1.50 a piece a few weeks late I went down at the next town and I went around looking a prices where there were 3 stores and I found the very same shirt selling for only $1.50. Oh the way our yanks have robbed us in the early days. It was something terrible. Well these crooks are all in their graves while we are still going strong.
